title: Trunk Impairment Scale
description: Quantifies disability after stroke; also validated in Parkinson's disease. Assesses static sitting balance, dynamic sitting balance, and coordination through 17 specific motor tasks.

parameters.name: static_item_1
parameters.description: Patient maintains starting position without support for 10 seconds

parameters.name: static_item_2
parameters.description: Therapist crosses unaffected leg over hemiplegic leg - patient maintains sitting position

parameters.name: static_item_3
parameters.description: Patient crosses unaffected leg over the hemiplegic leg

parameters.name: dynamic_item_1
parameters.description: Patient touches bed/table with hemiplegic elbow and returns to starting position

parameters.name: dynamic_item_4
parameters.description: Patient touches bed/table with unaffected elbow and returns to starting position

parameters.name: dynamic_item_7
parameters.description: Lifts pelvis at hemiplegic side and returns to starting position

parameters.name: dynamic_item_9
parameters.description: Lifts pelvis at unaffected side and returns to starting position

parameters.name: coordination_item_1
parameters.description: Rotates upper trunk 6x (each shoulder moved forward 3x), hemiplegic side must move first

parameters.name: coordination_item_3
parameters.description: Rotate lower trunk 6x (each knee moved forward 3x), hemiplegic side must move first

ranges.interpretation: Patient cannot maintain the basic sitting position without support for 10 seconds. This indicates severe trunk impairment requiring intensive rehabilitation and support. Complete assessment cannot be performed due to inability to maintain starting position.

Significant trunk motor impairment with limited static and dynamic sitting balance. Requires intensive rehabilitation focusing on basic trunk control and sitting balance. High risk for falls and functional limitations in daily activities.

Moderate trunk impairment with some preserved sitting balance but difficulties with dynamic movements and coordination. May benefit from targeted trunk rehabilitation exercises. Some functional activities may be compromised.
Mild trunk impairment with generally good sitting balance but some deficits in coordination or dynamic movements. Rehabilitation should focus on fine-tuning trunk control and coordination.
Excellent trunk function with minimal or no impairment. Good sitting balance, dynamic control, and coordination. May require minimal intervention or maintenance therapy.

references: Verheyden G, Nieuwboer A, Mertin J, Preger R, Kiekens C, De weerdt W. The Trunk Impairment Scale: a new tool to measure motor impairment of the trunk after stroke. Clin Rehabil. 2004;18(3):326-34.
Verheyden G, Willems AM, Ooms L, Nieuwboer A. Validity of the trunk impairment scale as a measure of trunk performance in people with Parkinson's disease. Arch Phys Med Rehabil. 2007;88(10):1304-8.
formula: Addition of points from 17 items divided into 3 categories: Static sitting balance (3 items, 0-7 points), Dynamic sitting balance (10 items, 0-10 points), and Coordination (4 items, 0-6 points). Special rule: If static item 1 = 0, total score = 0. Various dependency rules apply where failing certain items automatically scores 0 for related items.
notes: Starting position: Patient sits on edge of bed/table without back or arm support, thighs fully in contact with surface, knees bent at 90Â°, feet hip-width apart and flat on floor, arms resting on legs, head and trunk in midline position
Each item can be performed 3 times; the highest score is recorded
Tests are verbally explained and can be demonstrated if needed
If patient scores 0 on the first item (static sitting balance), the total score is 0
Originally developed for stroke assessment but also validated in Parkinson's disease
Dependency rules apply: failing certain dynamic or coordination items automatically scores 0 for related follow-up items
